title: Numerical prototypes
subtitle: Simple vacua, concrete spectra

content:
From algebra to spectra

Today we do something unambiguously testable in the mathematical sense: we take a concrete vacuum configuration ‚ü®H‚ü© ‚àà H‚ÇÉ(ùïÜ) and compute the spectrum of the associated mass map Œ†(‚ü®H‚ü©). No interpretation is needed to make this step meaningful: an operator has eigenvalues, and their multiplicities and gaps are rigid invariants.

The key point is that very simple choices of ‚ü®H‚ü© already generate spectra with a recognisable organisation: eigenvalues cluster into bands, bands split under controlled deformations, and the splitting patterns depend on which internal directions are activated. This is the first place where the exceptional machinery produces numerical prototypes rather than only symbolic structure.

Diagonal prototype vacua

Start with the cleanest vacuum in the Albert algebra, a diagonal element with three real parameters:

‚ü®H‚ü© = diag(Œª‚ÇÅ, Œª‚ÇÇ, Œª‚ÇÉ), Œª·µ¢ ‚àà ‚Ñù.

Even at this level, Œ†(‚ü®H‚ü©) is not ‚Äújust three numbers‚Äù: it is an endomorphism of the internal space, and the eigenvalue problem Œ†(‚ü®H‚ü©)Œ® = mŒ® produces a multiplet of masses m with definite degeneracies.

A diagonal ‚ü®H‚ü© is useful because it exposes the baseline band structure enforced by symmetry. Typically one finds eigenvalues arranged in a small number of clusters (bands), exact degeneracies dictated by residual internal symmetry, and clear gaps separating bands when (Œª‚ÇÅ,Œª‚ÇÇ,Œª‚ÇÉ) are non-equal.

Off-diagonal couplings: a better minimal example

The next step is not to solve a new cubic equation, but to switch on the smallest genuinely octonionic deformation and watch how symmetry protected degeneracies split. Consider a one-knob deformation with a single off-diagonal coupling:

‚ü®H‚ü© = [[Œª‚ÇÅ, Œµu, 0],[Œµ≈´, Œª‚ÇÇ, 0],[0, 0, Œª‚ÇÉ]], with u ‚àà ùïÜ, ‚Äñu‚Äñ = 1, Œµ ‚àà ‚Ñù.

What changes is qualitative and robust: degeneracies present at Œµ = 0 split into sub-bands for Œµ ‚â† 0; the existence of bands and gaps is stable under small changes of Œµ and of the direction u; and different choices of u produce characteristically different splitting patterns, reflecting how the internal algebra is wired into Œ†.

In other words, the simplest off-diagonal octonionic entry acts like a controlled spectral lever: it does not destroy the band structure, it refines it.

Prototype spectra: what is (and is not) claimed

These spectra are not yet precision predictions for Standard Model masses. What they provide is more basic and more reliable: an existence proof that the exceptional construction produces structured mass multiplets without inserting hierarchies by hand.

  1. Banded hierarchies: eigenvalues group into clusters separated by gaps, and the gaps persist under small deformations of the vacuum.
  2. Symmetry fingerprints: degeneracies and their splittings track residual symmetry and how it is broken by off-diagonal couplings.
  3. Continuity: varying (Œª‚ÇÅ,Œª‚ÇÇ,Œª‚ÇÉ,Œµ,u) moves eigenvalues continuously; qualitative patterns are structural, not tuned coincidences.

The message is simple: once Œ†(H) is fixed, numerical spectra are inevitable‚Äîand even minimal vacua already display the kind of organisation one would expect from a realistic mass sector.

An invitation to compute

After choosing a concrete basis, exploration reduces to diagonalising a structured real matrix. The point is not computational difficulty; it is that the exceptional input severely restricts what spectra can look like. A good first exercise is to compare the diagonal vacuum (Œµ = 0) to the one-knob deformation (Œµ ‚â† 0) and record which degeneracies split and which gaps remain.
closing: Even very simple vacua in H‚ÇÉ(ùïÜ) already yield banded, hierarchical spectra: numerical prototypes enforced by exceptional geometry.

intro:
To make exceptional algebra more than a catalogue of beautiful objects, one must eventually ask a brutally concrete question: what numbers does the structure force upon us? In the present framework this question has a clean and non-negotiable meaning. A vacuum choice is an element ‚ü®H‚ü© of the Albert algebra H‚ÇÉ(ùïÜ), and the model associates to it a linear operator Œ†(‚ü®H‚ü©) acting on an internal state space. From that point on, no additional physical narrative is required: an operator has a spectrum, with eigenvalues and multiplicities that are invariant under change of basis.

This shift of viewpoint is important. Instead of trying to ‚Äúguess‚Äù masses by attaching parameters to fields, we let the vacuum itself become an input to a spectral problem. The simplest vacua already reveal what is generic and what is accidental: bands versus isolated levels, symmetry-protected degeneracies versus controlled splittings, and gaps that persist under small deformations. In this sense, computing spectra is the most economical bridge from the exceptional geometry of H‚ÇÉ(ùïÜ) to concrete numerical prototypes.
